bad.work: The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul

title.reg: The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul

titlestmt.title: The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul: electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the Library of Congress

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 10KB; 6 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 79KB to 1300KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and Archives March 2010
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of 20 of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. These designs illustrate the Old Testament and are arranged according to the passages illustrated. They are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
The Bible had an enormous influence on Blake’s work as both artist and poet. Among his many and complex responses to that text are water color drawings. The present group of 20 is selected from a sequence of about 80 biblical water colors of similar size Blake painted for Thomas Butts between c. 1800 and 1805. These designs emphasize interactions between the human and the divine. In works such as Ezekiel’s Wheels and David Delivered Out of Many Waters , the interaction is revelatory or redemptive. In other designs, including Pestilence: The Death of the First-Born , the relationship between God and humankind devolves into punishment and destruction.
This group of 20 water colors is the first installment in our publication of a large selection of Blake’s water color drawings illustrating the Bible. In coming months we will publish a group of New Testament illustrations also from the series executed for Butts. Later we will add early works, such as Abraham and Isaac , datable to c. 1780, and continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, including Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes of c. 1824.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

title.hi: The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul

objdescid.origination: Anonymous delineator. The inscriptions on the mount, available under Related Works in the Archive, are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1800; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; probably the work offered at Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 166, titled "Witch of Endor" (7s. to "Butts," thus indicating that the lot was bought-in if Butts was the vendor); sold from the Butts collection, Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 112, titled "Saul and Samuel" (7s. to the dealer Henry G. Bohn); H. S. Drummond; sold Sotheby's, 29 Jan. 1912, lot 101 (£30 to "Dunthorne," probably a dealer); Greville Macdonald by 1914; the dealer Thomas Agnew & Sons; A. Edward Newton by 1926, sold from his collection at a Parke-Bernet auction, New York, 16 April 1941, lot 116 ($4,000 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, in 1945.

repository.addressline: Constitution Avenue NW, between 3rd and 9th Streets
Mailing Address: 2000B South Club Drive, Landover, Maryland 20785

desc.objtitle:
The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul,
object 1 (Butlin 458)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work, lower right, with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the card-like paper on which the inscriptions are written.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design illustrates 1 Samuel 28:7-19. Dominating the center of the design is the figure of the ghost of Samuel, an old, gowned man with long hair and a beard. He stands, facing forward, but twisted to face left and look down at Saul. He is slightly hunched over and he holds his arms at his sides, with both hands pointing down. His feet appear to be beneath the floor or tomb cover. To the left of the ghost of Samuel kneels Saul, a male figure with short, curly hair. He wears a tights and appears to have a sandal on his right foot. His mouth is open and he bends backward slightly as he crouches, looking right and up at Samuel's ghost. Saul's arms are raised horizontally, though bent upward with fingers spread. Both of his legs are bent. To the left of Saul, two disembodied male faces are visible. The leftmost one has a beard and flame-like hair, and faces right, mouth open, presumably looking at Samuel's ghost. The rightmost figure has short, curly hair and faces right and slightly forward, mouth open, presumably looking at Samuel's ghost. To the right of Samuel's ghost sits or squats the Witch of Endor (see 1 Samuel 28:7) with flame-like hair, clothed by a toga-like gown. She faces left, with her knees drawn up and her mouth open. She may look at Saul. Her left arm is bent upward and partly wrapped around her head; her right arm is raised vertically, fingers spread. She sits on a flat stone, perhaps part of a tomb. This scene appears to take place in at night, with the only light emanating from Samuel's ghost. The figures may be standing on the top of a tomb or grave from which Samuel's ghost has emerged.

component.illusobjdesc: Dominating the center of the design is the ghost of Samuel, an old, gowned man with long hair and a beard. He stands, facing forward, but twisted to face left and look down at Saul. He is slightly hunched over and he holds his arms at his sides, with both hands pointing down. His feet appear to be beneath the floor or tomb cover.

To the left of the ghost of Samuel kneels Saul, a male figure with short, curly hair. He wears tights and appears to have a sandal on his right foot. His mouth is open and he bends backward slightly as he crouches, looking right and up at Samuel's ghost. Saul's arms are raised horizontally, though bent upward with fingers spread. Both of his legs are bent. His gesture and expression suggest surprise.

To the left of Saul, two disembodied male faces are visible. The leftmost one has a beard and flame-like hair, and faces right, mouth open, presumably looking at Samuel's ghost. His facial expression suggests surprise.

To the left of Saul, two disembodied male faces are visible. The rightmost figure has short, curly hair and faces right and slightly forward, mouth open, presumably looking at Samuel's ghost. His facial expression suggests surprise.

To the right of Samuel's ghost sits or squats the Witch of Endor (see 1 Samuel 28:7). She has flame-like hair and is clothed by a toga-like gown. She faces left, with her knees drawn up and her mouth open. She may look at Saul. Her left arm is bent upward and partly wrapped around her head; her right arm is raised vertically, fingers spread.
The rightmost male figure sits on what appears to be a flat stone, perhaps part of a tomb or the cover of a grave extending below the other figures and from which Samuel's ghost has emerged.
This scene appears to take place in at night, with the only light emanating from Samuel's ghost. A shadow falls below the figures on the left.

desc.objtitle:
The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul,
full view including mount inscriptions

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the card-like paper on which the inscriptions are written.

desc.objtitle:
The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul,
top mount inscription

objnote.p: The inscription on the mount (the backing mat) above the design is not by Blake. It could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the card-like paper on which the inscription is written.

lg.l: And Saul said unto his servants,
seek me a woman that hath a familiar spirit.

desc.objtitle:
The Ghost of Samuel Appearing to Saul,
bottom mount inscriptions

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) below the design are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the card-like paper on which the inscriptions are written.

lg.l: 1: st Samuel 28: th ch: v. 12: th to 21. st
And Saul said to the woman, bring me up Samuel. And when the woman saw Samuel, she
cried with a loud voice, & spake to Saul, saying, why hast thou deceived me? for thou art Saul. And the king
said unto her, be not afraid, for what sawest thou? And the woman said unto Saul, I saw Gods ascending
out of the earth. And he said unto her, what form is he of? and she said, an old man cometh up, & and he is
covered with a mantle; And Saul perceived that it was Samuel & bowed himself to the ground. And
Samuel said unto Saul, why hast thou disquieted me, to bring me up.? And Saul answered, I am sore
distressed for the Philistenes war against me & God is departed from me & answereth me no more; therefore I have
called thee that thou mayest make known unto me what I am to do. Then said Samuel wherefore then asketh thou
of me, seeing the Lord hath departed from thee, & done as he spake by me for the Lord hath given thy kingdom to thy
neighbour David because thou obeydst not the voice of the Lord. Moreover the Lord will also deliver Israel with
thee into the hands of the Philistines & to morrow shalt thou and thy sons be with me.
